title: Who were the Rakshasa tribe mentioned in Hindu Mythology? - Quora

response.answer_text: First of all the question itself is absolutely wrong.  Devas were North Indians? Seriously!? Then what about Lord Ayyapan, Kubera, etc. !? Acc to Matsya Purāṇa, Śraddhādeva(Vaivasvata Manu) was the king of the Dravida Kingdom(South India) during the epoch of the Matsya Purāṇa. According to the Matsya Purāṇa, Matsya, the avatāra of Viṣṇu, first appeared as a shaphari (a small carp) to Śraddhādeva while he washed his hands in a river flowing down the Malaya Mountains,located in South India. And do you even know, that all the Devas are posts, not specific individuals. If anyone does good Karma, worthy enough to be a Deva, then he'll born as a Deva in the next cycle of Brahmāṇḍa. And Mahārāja Bali, a South Indian, is prophesied to be the next Indra. Hanumāna, another South Indian, will be the Brahmā after the next Brahmā. So Devas are not just North Indians. Zoroastrian Ahuras are not the evil Asuras of Hindu Pantheon! The Zoroastrian Ahuras are the Avestan version Ādityas or Devtās. It's true that the term Ahura comes from the Sanskrit word Asura, but Asura also means “mighty” or “powerful”. Even Viṣṇu, Indra, etc have also been addressed as Asuras in the Vedas.[1] And kiratas were also not only Mongoloids.[2][3][4] Vānara Vānara refers to a group of people living in forests, not a specific region. There are three main theories about the etymology of the word "Vānara": It derives from the word vana ("forest"), and means "belonging to the forest" or "forest-dwelling".It derives from the words vana ("forest") and nara ("man"), thus meaning "forest man".It derives from the words vav and nara, meaning "is it a man?" or "perhaps he is man".Kiṣkindhā was just a forest Kingdom, where the Vānaras ruled, that doesn't mean that they were only limited to Kiṣkindhā. Nāga Nāga, were also not restricted to any specific region. The city of Nagpur[5][6]has nothing to do with the Nāgas of Hindu Pantheon. And in the Itihāsas, Nāgas are depicted to be ruling various different regions, such as Māhiṣmatī, forests near Niṣāda, Northwest India near Takṣaśilā, Lohitya Kingdom in Kashmir & NorthEast India, KhāṇdavaPrastha(delhi), etc. and even outside India (Malaysia, Philippines, Burma). Rākṣasa There are two prominent stories about origin of Rākṣasas. One story says Rākṣasas were believed to have been created from the breath of Brahmā when he was asleep at the end of the Satya Yuga. As soon as they were created, they were so filled with bloodlust that they started eating Brahma himself. Brahma shouted "Rakshama!" (Sanskrit for "protect me!") and Viṣṇu came to his aid, banishing to Earth all Rākṣasas (named after Brahma's cry for help). Another story links the the origin of Rākṣasas to sage Pulastya(a son of Brahmā), alongwith Yakṣas, Vānaras & Kinnaras(Centaurs). Pulastya had a son named Viṣravā, who had two wives: Illavida and Kaikesi. Illavida was the mother of Yakṣas(Kubera) and Kaikesi was the mother of Rākṣasas(Rāvaṇa). Just like Daityas and Ādityas were step-brothers and always fought with each other, similarly Rākṣasas and Yakṣas always fought with each other. All the wealth accumulated by Yakṣas(Kubera) and kept at Laṅkā, was snatched by Rākṣasas(Rāvaṇa) and forced them to leave Laṅkā, and go to North. Traditionally Yakṣas are affiliated to North and Rākṣasas are affiliated to South. But in the Itihāsas there's no such regional boundations. Rākṣasas are mentioned to be living in various areas: Daṇdkāraṇya, Laṅkā, Forests of Sabarkantha dist. of Gujarat, Himalayan region between Gangotri & Kailash, Ekchakra, Kāmyaka, etc. Rākṣasas also attacked rishis, so Rishis clubbed the Rākṣasas with evil asuras of the later Vedic texts and Purāṇas. Rākṣasas are depicted to be ugly and barbarian, living in the forests, Rākṣasa lifestyle was based on either grabbing, hunting, snatching or sharing, an old tribal primitive uncivilized order. In some places, Rākṣasas are described as guardians (Rakṣā) of forest and in some places ‘Maneaters’ (Nri-chakshas). However all Rākṣasas were not evil or ugly. Several Rākṣasas such as Vibhīṣaṇa, Ghaṭōtkacha, Barbarīka, etc. are considered as one of the most noble beings in Hindu Pantheon. Vibhīṣaṇa is also described to be very handsome, and Śūrpaṇakhā's,a Rākṣasī(female Rākṣasa), physical appearance is described to be very alluring. Rākṣasas and Asuras(Daityas, Dānavas) are different. Daityas were the enemies of Ādityas, and lived in the Pātāla loka. Rākṣasas lived on Earth, and were more humanly by appearances. Rākṣasas were the enemies of Yakṣas, but also attacked humans. Western writers classify Vānara, Rākṣasa, Yakṣa, Nāga, etc. as Exotic tribes of ancient India, but that's absolutely wrong classification. They were supernatural and divine beings, not some tribe, acc to the Hindu mythology.
